Company Teaches Tax Avoidance Treasury officials say that abusive corporate tax shelters are the government's biggest tax enforcement problem, costing billions of dollars annually. Now a company called the Tax People is teaching similar tax avoidance techniques to middle-class Americans and says it has already signed up 50,000 of them. [A1.]

Hewlett Rolls Out New Computer Hewlett-Packard rolled out the powerful computer it is counting on to lift sales to companies that need systems capable of handling huge amounts of data around the clock. Carly S. Fiorina, Hewlett-Packard's chief executive, hailed the new computer, called Superdome, as a symbol of the company's claim that it has been ''reinvented'' as a more customer-oriented vendor selling solutions rather than products. Ms. Fiorina did not mention the company's talks to acquire the consulting arm of PricewaterhouseCoopers, but analysts said that such a deal would be consistent with the vision involved in Superdome. Shares of Hewlett-Packard fell $2.19, to $112.56. [C6.]

Merger of Exchanges Abandoned The London Stock Exchange scrapped its proposal to merge with the Frankfurt stock exchange, abandoning for now an effort to create the first pan-European stock market. [C4.]

Burger King Puts Account in Review Burger King placed the creative duties for its general market advertising account, involving assignments with billings estimated at $400 million, in review. The incumbent agency, the New York office of Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide, is being invited to participate in the review, but the company said it would be expected to offer a drastically new approach to the account. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C12.]

Nasdaq Declines, but Dow Edges Up Technology stocks declined, but blue chips rose modestly, driven by the surging shares of J. P. Morgan. The Nasdaq composite index fell 46.84 points, or 1.2 percent, to 3,849.51. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 37.74 points, or 0.3 percent, to 11,233.23. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was down 7.27 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,481.99. [C18.]

Creating a Supportive Atmosphere Royal Farros, the chief executive of iPrint.com, an online printing service, says managing a company involves a lot of the same expectations and feelings as having pets. Creating a loving, affectionate home for pets is similar to fostering an active environment where employees feel important and influential. Building such a culture is not just critical to the personality of an organization, he says, but absolutely key to its livelihood. The Boss. [C8.]

Political Volunteers in White Collars For all the fund-raising by Democrats and Republicans this year, candidates for offices from the the White House to the local school board know one thing is even more important than money: volunteers. And while these unpaid armies are made up mostly of students and retired people, it is business professionals who exhibit the qualities that political candidates value most: nuts-and-bolts organizational skills, management savvy and address books filled with contacts. Management. [C8.]

Travel Departments Toughen Limits With estimates that business air fares, hotel rates and car rentals will rise by at least 5 percent next year, many travel departments are revamping travel policies or drafting new ones -- and insisting on more strict adherence to them. Joe Sharkey: Business Travel. [C10.]
